P.title: Will the price of water on the NQH20 hit $2,500 (2021 USD) per acre-foot by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the price of water hits $2500, adjusted for inflation to 2021 USD, on the NQH20 by 2050-01-01, 00:00 UTC. This question resolves negatively if the price of water does not hit $2500 by that date, and it resolves ambiguously if the NQH20 or a similar exchange doesn't continuously track California water prices up until 2050

Resolution Criteria
This inquiry will be considered true if the price of water reaches $2500, adjusted for inflation to 2021 USD, on the NQH20 by 2050-01-01, 00:00 UTC. This inquiry will be deemed false if the price of water does not reach $2500 by that date, and it will be regarded as unclear if the NQH20 or a similar market does not consistently follow California water prices until 2050

P.title: Will the Forethought Foundation have more than two full-time equivalent employees in 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For the purposes of this question, a full-time equivalent is defined as working 35 hours per week, without including volunteers. Question will be resolved negatively if the project has clearly been abandoned, otherwise, reports by the organization together with best estimates by Metaculus moderators will be used

P.title: If Joe Biden is elected president of the US in 2020, will the highest tax bracket be restored to its original 39.6% or higher before 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Joe Biden is elected president for the 2021-2024 term, and the upper tax bracket for US single tax payers is increased to at least 39.6% by January 1, 2025. If Biden is elected but the upper tax bracket is not increased to at least 39.6%, this question will resolve as No.
If Biden is not elected President in 2020, this question will resolve as Ambiguous

para_P.title: In the event that Joe Biden becomes the president of the United States in 2020, will the top tax rate be reinstated to its former level of 39.6% or more prior to 2025?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This inquiry will be answered with Yes if Joe Biden is elected as president for the term from 2021 to 2024, and the highest tax rate for individual taxpayers in the US is raised to a minimum of 39.6% by January 1, 2025. If Biden is elected but the top tax rate does not reach at least 39.6%, the answer will be No.
If Biden does not win the presidency in 2020, this question will be considered Ambiguous.

P.title: Will smoking and sex be less prevalent in the United States in 2050 than in 2021?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys of US adults in the year 2050 report that the share of adults who have smoked in the past week and the share of adults who have had sex in the past week were both lower than in the year 2021. Comparisons between 2050 and 2021 must be of similar methodology (see fine print) to count towards resolution. If no comparable surveys can be found for both smoking and sex by the resolution date of December 31, 2054, this question will resolve as Ambiguous. This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys would result in positive resolution, conflicting surveys will be considered irrelevant.
Fine Print
Regarding similar methodology, if a survey in 2021 includes e-cigarettes and a survey from 2050 does not the surveys would not be considered to have similar methodology. However, different methodologies can still be acceptable if it can be logically deduced that the surveys provide evidence toward resolution. For example, if a survey in 2021 asked whether respondents had sex in the past year and 25% answered no, and a survey in 2050 asked if respondents had sex in the past five years and 40% answered no, it can be deduced that a larger share of adults in 2050 had not had sex in the past year than in 2021 because the five year period would include the past year.

This question will be considered affirmative if any trustworthy surveys conducted among US adults in 2050 show that the percentage of adults who smoked in the last week and the percentage of adults who participated in sexual activity in the last week are both lower than the statistics recorded in 2021. To ensure valid comparisons between 2050 and 2021, the surveys must employ similar methodologies (see fine print). If no comparable surveys for both smoking and sexual activity are available by the resolution deadline of December 31, 2054, this question will be deemed Ambiguous. The question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys provide a positive result; conflicting surveys will not be considered.
Fine Print
Regarding similar methodology, if a 2021 survey includes e-cigarettes while a 2050 survey does not, those surveys will not be viewed as having similar methodologies. However, differing methodologies may still be acceptable if it can be logically inferred that the surveys yield relevant evidence for resolution. For example, if a 2021 survey asked whether respondents had sexual intercourse in the past year and 25% answered no, while a 2050 survey asked if respondents had sexual intercourse in the last five years and 40% answered no, it can be inferred that a larger proportion of adults in 2050 had not engaged in sexual activity in the past year compared to 2021, since the five-year period includes the past year.

P.title: Will there be adversarial use of consumer genomic data before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the New York Times (or another similarly reputable source) reports, before January 1 2030, on the following having occurred:
Genetic data collected through either medical testing or direct-to-consumer products
Is used to inflict harm on one or more individuals
Without their consent
Fine Print
Recognizing that "harm" and "consent" can be fuzzy, here are some examples meant to clarify the intent of the question.
The following examples do not count as positive resolutions:
Speculation that such a harm is possible, plausible, or likely
Genetic data is leaked or hacked but there is no evidence about specific harmful uses resulting from this.
Genetic data is collected in a bespoke way for the purposes of harm (eg a state power collects DNA from a targeted individual).
Individuals suffer psychic harm from discovering family infidelities (this is so common already that it is "baked in" to consent).
The following examples do count as positive resolutions:
Evidence of discrimination or insurance rates being set from individual-level genomics without explicit customer authorization ("would you like to submit your DNA profile to Anthem?"), even if legal and authorized under a vague terms of service
An outside actor gaining access to genomics data, learning about family infidelities, and publishing this broadly.

Is employed to cause harm to one or more persons
Without their approval
Fine Print
Understanding that "harm" and "approval" can be ambiguous, here are some examples intended to clarify the purpose of this question.
The following scenarios do not qualify as positive resolutions:
Theoretical discussions about the possibility, plausibility, or likelihood of such harm
Genetic information is compromised or hacked, but there is no proof of specific harmful applications resulting from this.
Genetic information is gathered in a tailored manner for harmful purposes (e.g., a governmental entity collects DNA from a targeted individual).
Individuals experience emotional distress from learning about family secrets (this is so prevalent that it is considered inherent to consent).
The following scenarios do qualify as positive resolutions:
Proof of discrimination or insurance pricing determined by individual genomic data without explicit customer consent (e.g., "Would you like to share your DNA profile with Anthem?"), even if it is legal and permitted under vague terms of service
An external party accessing genomic information, discovering family secrets, and widely publishing this information.

Individuals experience emotional distress from uncovering family secrets (this is so prevalent that it is considered part of the consent process).
The following scenarios do count as positive resolutions:
Proof of discrimination or insurance premiums being determined based on individual genomic data without clear customer consent (e.g., "Would you like to provide your DNA profile to Anthem?"), even if it is legal and permitted under ambiguous terms of service.
An external entity accessing genomic data, discovering family secrets, and widely disseminating this information.

para_P.title: Will consumer genomic data be used maliciously before 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the New York Times (or another similarly reputable source) reports, before January 1 2030, on the following having occurred:
Genetic data collected through either medical testing or direct-to-consumer products
Is used to inflict harm on one or more individuals
Without their consent
Fine Print
Recognizing that "harm" and "consent" can be fuzzy, here are some examples meant to clarify the intent of the question.
The following examples do not count as positive resolutions:
Speculation that such a harm is possible, plausible, or likely
Genetic data is leaked or hacked but there is no evidence about specific harmful uses resulting from this.
Genetic data is collected in a bespoke way for the purposes of harm (eg a state power collects DNA from a targeted individual).
Individuals suffer psychic harm from discovering family infidelities (this is so common already that it is "baked in" to consent).
The following examples do count as positive resolutions:
Evidence of discrimination or insurance rates being set from individual-level genomics without explicit customer authorization ("would you like to submit your DNA profile to Anthem?"), even if legal and authorized under a vague terms of service
An outside actor gaining access to genomics data, learning about family infidelities, and publishing this broadly.

P.title: Will there be Human-machine intelligence parity before 2040?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves as YES if the machine system outscores at least two of the three humans on the following test prior to 2040, or NO otherwise. If no such tests are conducted, resolves as AMBIGUOUS.
Assume that prior to 2040, a generalized intelligence test will be administered as follows. A team of three expert interviewers will interact with a candidate machine system (MS) and three humans (3H). The humans will be graduate students in each of physics, mathematics and computer science from one of the top 25 research universities (per some recognized list), chosen independently of the interviewers. The interviewers will electronically communicate (via text, image, spoken word, or other means) an identical series of exam questions of their choosing over a period of two hours to the MS and 3H, designed to advantage the 3H. Both MS and 3H have full access to the internet, but no party is allowed to consult additional humans, and we assume the MS is not an internet-accessible resource. The exam will be scored blindly by a disinterested third party.
Note that this also effectively tests whether the internet as a whole functions as a human-level intelligence, in that a positive resolution indicates that the human participants are effectively superfluous.

para_P.title: Will Human-machine intelligence reach equivalence before the year 2040?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This inquiry will resolve positively if the machine system achieves a higher score than at least two out of the three human participants on the specified test prior to 2040, or negatively otherwise. If no tests are performed, the resolution will be deemed AMBIGUOUS.

The evaluators will deliver (through text, images, spoken communication, or other methods) an identical set of examination questions of their choosing over a span of two hours to both the MS and 3H, designed to favor the human participants. Both the MS and 3H will have unlimited access to the internet, but no participant is allowed to consult additional humans, and it is assumed that the MS does not serve as an internet-accessible resource. The examination will be assessed anonymously by an unbiased third party.
It is crucial to highlight that this also effectively evaluates whether the internet functions as a human-level intelligence, as a successful outcome indicates that the human participants are essentially redundant.

P.title: Will a non-state actor have acquired a nuclear weapon from a state by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, between this question opening and 2030-01-01, an individual or group who is not in a state's nuclear chain of command has possession of a nuclear weapon that was originally developed by a state and is in deployable condition at the time the state acquires it (though it need not be used, detonated, or set on alert). This may occur (for example) by sales, theft, or a state inadvertently losing control of a weapon. This will not include cases where a non-state actor independently develops a weapon (such scenarios are addressed in a separate question).
A non-state actor obtaining highly-enriched uranium or other weapons material is not sufficient to resolve this question positively. Additionally, dirty bombs (conventional weapons which use radioactive material to spread fallout) do not qualify for this question; the weapon must be a nuclear weapon in the sense of having nuclear fission or fusion as its primary energy source.
This question will resolve on the basis of official statements by governments, government intelligence authorities, or non-governmental nuclear intelligence organizations. In the case of significant disagreement or ambiguity on the points above, resolution may be delayed until 2035-01-01 for clarification, or be resolved ambiguous at the discretion of Metaculus admins

para_P.title: By the year 2030, will a non-state entity have gained possession of a nuclear weapon that was developed by a state?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This inquiry will be considered affirmative if, from the time this question is posed until January 1, 2030, a person or collective that is not part of a state's nuclear command chain possesses a nuclear weapon that was originally created by a state and is in a state ready for deployment at the moment it is acquired (although it does not need to be activated, detonated, or placed on alert). This could happen through various means such as sale, theft, or a state unintentionally losing control over a weapon. Instances where a non-state entity independently creates a nuclear weapon will not be included (such cases are covered in a different question).
The acquisition of highly-enriched uranium or similar materials by a non-state actor does not suffice to affirm this question. Furthermore, the concept of dirty bombs (standard explosives utilizing radioactive material to disperse fallout) does not meet the criteria for this question; the weapon must be classified as a nuclear weapon in terms of utilizing nuclear fission or fusion as its main energy source.
The resolution of this question will rely on official declarations from governments, intelligence agencies, or independent nuclear monitoring organizations. If there is notable disagreement or uncertainty regarding the aforementioned points, the resolution may be postponed until January 1, 2035 for further clarification, or may be deemed ambiguous at the discretion of Metaculus administrators.

P.title: Will SpaceX land anything on Mars before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a SpaceX-branded mission, where the primary launch hardware and Mars entry, descent, and landing systems are built by SpaceX, successfully lands on the surface of Mars by January 1, 2030. A landing's "success" will be judged by the intent of the mission according to SpaceX.
A "SpaceX-branded" mission is defined to mean that the SpaceX-associated logos on the spacecraft involved (both the boosters and the Mars-bound craft) have a larger surface area than the logos of any other entity

P.title: Will the FDA or EMA withdraw approval of Semaglutide for the treatment of obesity by 2027?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if either the US Food and Drug Administration or the European Medicines Agency withdraw approval for Semaglutide (AKA Wegovy, Ozempic, or any other brand name for semaglutide 2.4 mg weekly injection) by 2027-01-01. P.title: If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations, will humanity's population be less than 400 million 50 years later?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, 50 years after the final detonation as part of the first nuclear conflict (before January 1, 2100) which involves >1,000 offensive nuclear detonations, humanity's population is below 400 million. This would include, but is not limited to, scenarios in which humanity is extinct. The resolution of this question is not affected by whether, 50 years after the final detonation, the population is stable, rising, or falling; it is only affected by whether it is below 400 million.
This question will resolve as Ambiguous if there is no nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations by January 1, 2100.
For the purposes of this question, "humans" will be considered members of a species who could typically reproduce with typical 2021 humans without medical assistance. In scenarios where this question would resolve positively given that definition, but there remain >400 million beings that at least one 2021 Metaculus moderator would consider "human" (possible examples: some human-like digital minds; some possible types of genetically altered humans), this question will instead resolve ambiguously. This is because it is debatable whether such scenarios should count as population collapses.
Fine Print
No attempt will be made to distinguish the effects of the nuclear conflict from the effects of other events. That is, even if it's mere coincidence that the population declines and/or that it remains low following the nuclear conflict, the question can still resolve positively.
We request that you forecast your true beliefs despite the fact that a Metaculus scores may be unlikely to be tracked or cared about if this question resolves positively, given that forecasts on this question may play a role in informing important decisions.

P.title: Will a non-test nuclear detonation by a non-state actor cause at least one fatality by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A nuclear detonation by a non-state actor could potentially have dire consequences either directly or via triggering other harmful actions by other actors. Non-state actors have never yet detonated nuclear weapons, but there are conceivable scenarios in which they could:
The majority of nuclear security experts identify two primary scenarios involving nuclear weapons and non-state actors. The first scenario involves the acquisition of a nuclear device from the existing arsenals of nuclear-armed States by terrorists or other non-state actors. The second scenario envisions the construction of a crude nuclear bomb by non-state actors using special nuclear materials—highly enriched uranium (HEU) or plutonium (Pu). The actualization of each of these scenarios would be very difficult, and the probability of a successful theft and detonation of an actual nuclear weapon or manufacturing of an improvised device by non-state actors is considered to be low. Yet, this probability is not zero.
Will a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor causes at least one fatality by 2030?
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor causes at least one fatality in any country or area globally.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation, so a fatality caused by things like fallout, rioting, or climate effects will not count towards a positive resolution.
Resolution criteria will be gathered from reliable news sources or from direct government or multi-national reports such as from the UN.
Neither detonations for testing purposes nor peaceful nuclear explosions will count towards question resolution, even if such detonations cause substantial damage.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to the resolution council or Metaculus admins.

para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A nuclear explosion executed by a non-state entity could lead to severe outcomes, either directly or by inciting further harmful actions from other parties. To date, non-state entities have never detonated nuclear weapons, yet there are plausible scenarios in which this could occur:
Most nuclear security specialists recognize two main scenarios concerning nuclear weapons and non-state entities. The first scenario involves terrorists or other non-state entities obtaining a nuclear device from the existing stockpiles of nuclear-armed nations. The second scenario imagines non-state entities creating a rudimentary nuclear bomb using special nuclear materials—highly enriched uranium (HEU) or plutonium (Pu). The realization of these scenarios would be extremely challenging, and the likelihood of a non-state entity successfully stealing and detonating a genuine nuclear weapon or fabricating an improvised device is regarded as low. P.title: Is it possible for a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor to cause at least one fatality by the year 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A nuclear detonation executed by a non-state actor could have dire consequences either directly or by provoking further harmful actions by other entities. Historically, non-state actors have never set off nuclear devices, but there are credible scenarios in which this could happen:
Most nuclear security experts highlight two primary scenarios involving nuclear weapons and non-state actors. The first scenario involves terrorists or other non-state groups obtaining a nuclear weapon from the existing arsenals of nuclear-capable nations. The second scenario considers the creation of a basic nuclear device by non-state actors using special nuclear materials—highly enriched uranium (HEU) or plutonium (Pu). Achieving either scenario would be incredibly difficult, and the chances of successfully stealing and detonating a nuclear weapon or fabricating an improvised device by non-state actors are regarded as low. However, this possibility is not entirely ruled out.

This question will receive an affirmative answer if, before January 1, 2030, a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor results in at least one death in any location worldwide.
The death must be a direct result of the explosion, thus fatalities due to fallout, civil disorder, or environmental consequences will not be counted towards a positive resolution.

Explosions intended for testing or peaceful nuclear purposes will not be counted in the resolution of this question, even if they cause significant harm.
Test explosions and peaceful nuclear detonations are defined as those officially acknowledged to be tests or peaceful nuclear explosions by a government statement within 30 days of the event, without contradiction from credible media, state reports, or international reports. If the information is unclear, the resolution will be decided by the resolution council or Metaculus administrators.

para_P.title: Is it possible for a nuclear detonation executed by a non-state actor to cause at least one fatality by the year 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A nuclear detonation carried out by a non-state group could have dire repercussions, either directly or by inciting further detrimental actions. Although non-state organizations have never triggered nuclear explosions, there are conceivable situations in which they could:
Most experts in nuclear security point out two primary scenarios involving nuclear weapons and non-state actors. The first scenario entails terrorists or other non-state organizations acquiring a nuclear weapon from the arsenals of nuclear-capable nations. The second scenario involves non-state agents fabricating a basic nuclear device using specialized nuclear materials—highly enriched uranium (HEU) or plutonium (Pu). Both scenarios present substantial hurdles, and the chances of successfully stealing and detonating an actual nuclear weapon or constructing an improvised device by non-state actors are deemed low. Nevertheless, this probability is not nonexistent.
Is it feasible for a nuclear detonation by a non-state group to lead to at least one death by 2030?
This inquiry will be answered affirmatively if, prior to January 1, 2030, a nuclear explosion by a non-state actor results in at least one death anywhere globally.
The fatality must be a direct consequence of the explosion, thus deaths arising from fallout, civil unrest, or environmental impacts will not count towards a positive resolution.
Resolution criteria will rely on credible news outlets or direct accounts from governmental or international bodies, such as those from the UN.
Explosions conducted for testing or peaceful nuclear objectives will not be included in the resolution of this question, even if they inflict significant damage.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as those officially recognized as tests or peaceful nuclear detonations by a government statement within 30 days of the incident, without contradiction from credible media, state reports, or international reports. If the information is ambiguous, the resolution will be determined by the resolution council or Metaculus administrators.

P.title: In 2029, will the US have 3,800 or fewer nuclear weapons?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The size of the US's nuclear weapons stockpile reached a peak in 1966 at around 30,000 warheads. Following the deescalation and the end of the Cold War, the number has substantially decreased. Kristensen and Korda (2019) estimate that the US maintains a deployed stockpile of nearly 3,800 warheads. The approximate breakdown is as follows:
1,750 warheads are currently deployed, of which
1,300 strategic warheads are deployed on ballistic missiles,
300 at strategic bomber bases in the United States,
150 tactical bombs are deployed at air bases in Europe.
2,050 are in storage as a so-called hedge against technical or geopolitical surprises.
It is possible that this trend will reverse in a period of nuclear rearmament, especially if world tensions get worse. The Trump Administration’s Nuclear Posture Review takes a confrontational tone, presenting an assertive posture that embraces “Great Power competition” and includes plans to expand the US' nuclear arsenal.
In 2029, will the US have 3,800 or fewer nuclear weapons?
This resolves positive if credible sources, such as the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists' Nuclear Notebook (such as this one for 2019) reports that the US held 3,800 (or fewer) nuclear warheads at any time in 2029. A similar credible source may be consulted if the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists in no longer active or publishing reports. For the purposes of question resolution, warheads that are retired and awaiting dismantlement will not be counted.
See also the related question, If the US does not pursue nuclear disarmament, how many nuclear warheads will it have in 2029?

para_P.title: By the year 2029, will the United States possess 3,800 or fewer nuclear warheads?
para_P.body:
Criteria for Resolution
The peak number of nuclear weapons in the US arsenal was approximately 30,000 warheads in 1966. After the Cold War and a reduction in tensions, this number has significantly declined. According to Kristensen and Korda (2019), the US currently has a deployed stockpile estimated at nearly 3,800 warheads. The current distribution is as follows:
1,750 warheads are actively deployed, which includes
1,300 strategic warheads on ballistic missiles,
300 stationed at strategic bomber bases within the United States,
150 tactical bombs located at airbases in Europe.
Additionally, 2,050 warheads are kept in storage as a precaution against unforeseen technical or geopolitical events.
There is a possibility that this downward trend may reverse if there is a resurgence in nuclear armament, especially in the face of escalating global tensions. The Nuclear Posture Review from the Trump Administration adopts a confrontational stance, advocating for a vigorous approach to "Great Power competition" and outlining intentions to bolster the US nuclear arsenal.
By the year 2029, will the United States have 3,800 or fewer nuclear warheads?
This question is answered affirmatively if credible sources, such as the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists' Nuclear Notebook (for instance, the 2019 report), indicate that the US had 3,800 (or fewer) nuclear warheads at any point in 2029. Should the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists cease to operate or publish reports, an alternative credible source may be referenced. For the resolution of this question, retired warheads awaiting dismantlement will not be included in the count.
Additionally, consider the related inquiry: If the US does not engage in nuclear disarmament, what will be the number of nuclear warheads it possesses in 2029?

A positive response to this inquiry will be given if credible sources, such as the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists' Nuclear Notebook (similar to the 2019 edition), report that the US had 3,800 (or fewer) nuclear warheads at any point during 2029. Should the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists cease operations or publication, another reliable source may be used. For resolution purposes, warheads that have been retired and are waiting for dismantlement will not be counted.
Refer to the related question: If the US does not engage in nuclear disarmament, what will the number of nuclear warheads it possesses in 2029?

para_P.title: By 2029, will the United States have 3,800 or fewer nuclear warheads in its arsenal?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The peak quantity of nuclear warheads in the US arsenal was noted in 1966, reaching around 30,000. Since the end of the Cold War, this figure has drastically reduced. As per Kristensen and Korda (2019), the current active stockpile of the US is nearly 3,800 warheads. The estimated distribution includes:
1,750 warheads presently deployed, which consists of
1,300 strategic warheads on ballistic missiles,
300 located at strategic bomber bases within the US,
150 tactical bombs positioned at air bases in Europe.
Furthermore, there are 2,050 warheads reserved as a safeguard against technical or geopolitical uncertainties.
This downward trend might change if nuclear rearmament takes place, especially with rising global tensions. The Nuclear Posture Review from the Trump Administration adopts an aggressive approach, highlighting “Great Power competition” and suggesting a possible increase in the US nuclear stockpile.
Will the US possess 3,800 or fewer nuclear warheads by the year 2029?
A positive response to this inquiry will be provided if credible sources, such as the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists' Nuclear Notebook (similar to the 2019 edition), indicate that the US had 3,800 (or fewer) nuclear warheads at any time during 2029. If the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists ceases operations or publication, an alternative reputable source may be utilized. For the purpose of resolution, warheads that have been retired and are awaiting dismantlement will not be counted.
Refer to the related question: If the US does not engage in nuclear disarmament, what will be the total number of nuclear warheads it possesses in 2029?

Resolution Criteria
The highest number of nuclear warheads in the US arsenal was recorded in 1966, peaking at approximately 30,000. Since the Cold War's conclusion, this number has significantly declined. 1,750 warheads currently deployed, comprising
1,300 strategic warheads mounted on ballistic missiles,
300 stationed at strategic bomber bases in the US,

P.title: Will the WTA and ATP merge before 2031?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both men and women play as part of one tour with one tour organiser in top competitive Tennis. It will also resolve as Yes if not all tournaments are mixed (ie if some currently all-female or all-male tournaments are part of the tour, that doesn't trigger negative resolution as long as the overarching tour organiser is one body)
This question will resolve as No if men and women play as part of two separate tours on the basis of gender.
In the event that it is unclear (eg the tennis tour fractures into multiple tours (WTA, ATP, mixed tour)) we will ask Jeff Sackmann's opinion and resolve at his discretion. (In the event he says it's unclear / is uncontactable / unwilling to decide, the question will resolve as Ambiguous

para_P.title: Will the WTA and ATP combine into a single entity before 2031?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will be answered as Yes if both male and female players compete under one unified tour organized by a single governing body in top-tier Tennis. It will also be considered Yes if not every tournament is co-ed (i.e., if some tournaments remain exclusively male or female but are included under the same tour organization, this will not lead to a negative resolution as long as there is one overarching tour organizer).
This question will be answered as No if male and female players continue to compete in two distinct tours based on gender.
If the situation becomes ambiguous (for example, if the tennis tour splits into several tours such as WTA, ATP, and a mixed tour), we will consult Jeff Sackmann for his judgment, and the resolution will be at his discretion. If he finds it unclear, cannot be reached, or is unwilling to make a decision, the question will resolve as Ambiguous.

P.title: Will humanity maintain a continuous off-Earth presence until 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Since October 31 2000, the date Soyuz TM-31 lifted off from the Baikonur Cosmodrome carrying the members of Expedition 1, the first long-duration ISS crew, humanity has maintained a permanent off-Earth presence for more than 19 years.
This question asks: Will humanity maintain an off-Earth presence continuously until 1 January 2050?
For a positive resolution, at least one living and conscious biological human must be physically located at some point beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times continuously until 1 January 2050. This could include persons aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as persons on any astronomical object other than Earth (e.g. Moon or Mars explorers / settlers).
If the number of living and conscious biological humans off-Earth drops to zero at any time before 1 January 2050, this question resolves negatively. EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either wholly non-biological or non-conscious humans will not count for the purposes of this question. Humans who are merely sleeping will be considered conscious for the purposes of this question.
However, biological humans with some degree of cybernetic augmentation (brain implants, artificial limbs or organs, etc) will suffice, so long as they could still reproduce with un-augmented humans.

para_P.title: Will humanity sustain an uninterrupted off-planet presence until the year 2050?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Since the launch of Soyuz TM-31 from the Baikonur Cosmodrome on October 31, 2000, which carried the members of Expedition 1, the inaugural long-duration crew of the ISS, humanity has upheld a continuous off-planet presence for over 19 years.
This inquiry seeks to determine: Will humanity uphold an off-planet presence without interruption until January 1, 2050?
For a positive outcome, at least one living and aware biological human must be situated at some point beyond 100 kilometers above Earth's average sea level at all times continuously until January 1, 2050. This may encompass individuals aboard spacecraft and space stations, in addition to those on any celestial bodies other than Earth (for instance, explorers or settlers on the Moon or Mars).
If the count of living and aware biological humans off-planet falls to zero at any moment before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve negatively. EMs, artificial intelligence entities, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other forms of either entirely non-biological or non-conscious humans will not be considered for this question. Humans who are simply asleep will be deemed conscious for the purposes of this inquiry.
Nonetheless, biological humans with some level of cybernetic enhancement (such as brain implants, artificial limbs, or organs, etc.) will be acceptable, provided they are still capable of reproduction with unenhanced humans.

P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Since the launch of Soyuz TM-31 on October 31, 2000, which carried the first long-term crew of the ISS, known as Expedition 1, humanity has upheld a continuous presence off the planet for over 19 years.
This inquiry seeks to determine: Will humanity uphold a continuous presence beyond Earth until January 1, 2050?
For a positive outcome, there must be at least one living, aware biological human located at some point above 100 kilometers in altitude from Earth's average sea level at all times continuously until January 1, 2050. This could encompass individuals aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as those on any celestial body other than Earth (e.g., explorers or settlers on the Moon or Mars).
If the count of living and aware biological humans off the planet falls to zero at any moment before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve negatively. Emergency measures, artificial intelligence, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either entirely non-biological or non-aware humans will not qualify for this question. Humans who are simply asleep will be regarded as aware for this inquiry.
Nonetheless, biological humans with some level of cybernetic enhancement (such as brain implants, artificial limbs, or organs) will be acceptable, provided they are still capable of reproducing with unenhanced humans.

This question inquires: Will humans sustain an uninterrupted off-Earth presence until January 1, 2050?
For a positive outcome, at least one living and conscious biological human must be physically located beyond 100km altitude above Earth's mean sea level at all times continuously until January 1, 2050. This includes individuals aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as those on any celestial body other than Earth (e.g., Moon or Mars explorers/settlers).
If the count of living and conscious biological humans off-Earth drops to zero at any point before January 1, 2050, this question resolves negatively. EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other instances of either entirely non-biological or non-conscious humans will not be considered for this question. Humans who are merely sleeping will be regarded as conscious for the purposes of this question.
However, biological humans with some degree of cybernetic enhancement (brain implants, artificial limbs or organs, etc.) will be acceptable, provided they can still reproduce with un-augmented humans.

For a positive conclusion, at least one living and aware biological human must be positioned more than 100 kilometers above Earth's average sea level at all times, without interruption, until January 1, 2050. This includes individuals aboard spacecraft and space stations, as well as those on any celestial body other than Earth (for example, explorers or settlers on the Moon or Mars).
If the number of living and aware biological humans off-planet falls to zero at any moment prior to January 1, 2050, this question will receive a negative answer. Entities such as EMs, artificial intelligence systems, humans in suspended animation or cryopreservation, and all other forms of either entirely non-biological or non-conscious humans will not be factored into this question. Humans who are simply sleeping will be deemed conscious for the purposes of this inquiry.
However, biological humans with some degree of cybernetic enhancement (such as brain implants, artificial limbs or organs, etc.) will be regarded as valid, provided they remain capable of reproduction with un-augmented humans.

P.title: Will Turkey be a NATO member continuously until January 1, 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Turkey is a NATO member continuously from October 1, 2019 to January 1, 2025. The question will resolve as No if Turkey is suspended or expelled from NATO, or if it withdraws of its own accord, at any time before January 1, 2025.
If before this question resolves NATO is dissolved, or changed in structure or operation so substantially that Metaculus administrators believe it is no longer prudent to continue this question, this question shall resolve as Ambiguous

P.title: Who will be elected to be US President in 2024? (Kamala Harris)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the person who wins the 2024 US presidential election, and No for all other options. This will be the person who wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment.
This question is not limited to the individuals currently listed below; the question may resolve as No for all listed options, and options may be added later.
Fine Print
This question does not require that the individual winning the 2024 Election wins the popular vote, be projected by news media as winning the election, or to be officially inaugurated or perform any duty of the US President, only that they have been selected by the Electoral College or by US Congress.
In the event that there is no election or certification of the vote by February 1, 2025, this question will resolve as Ambiguous for all options.

If there is no election or vote confirmation by February 1, 2025, this question will be classified as Ambiguous for all candidates.

P.title: Will any top 10 global meat processor/producer go bankrupt before 2028?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Cargill, Tyson Foods, Hormel, Muyuan Foods, Wens Foodstuff Group, or any of their parent companies file for bankruptcy by January 1, 2028, according to credible financial media reports.
This question will resolve positively if Cargill, Tyson Foods or Hormel (or any of their parent companies) submits a court filing seeking bankruptcy protection under any provision of the United States Bankruptcy Code, or if Muyuan Foods or Wens Foodstuff Group (or any of their parent companies) apply for bankruptcy proceedings in China. It will also resolve positively if Kerry Group applies for bankruptcy proceedings in Ireland, JBS in Brazil, the WH Group in Hong Kong, Mowi ASA in Norway, or the Marubeni Corporation in Japan.
Positive resolution requires a filing only. No court ruling needs to be made.
If any of the relevant companies are acquired or merged, and the new entity files for bankruptcy within two years of the acquisition or merger, the question will resolve positively

This question will be answered affirmatively if Cargill, Tyson Foods, Hormel, Muyuan Foods, Wens Foodstuff Group, or any of their parent companies file for bankruptcy by January 1, 2028, as reported by reliable financial news sources.
